summary: i'm so uncomfortable calling sansa's time as a hostage a 'be careful what you wish for' experience because sansa didn't wish for...
body: i’m so uncomfortable calling sansa’s time as a hostage a ‘be careful what you wish for’ experience because sansa didn’t wish for anything resembling that. she wanted feasts, tourneys and a happy marriage as an 11 year old child. yet that’s what acok and asos (more acok than asos tbh) feels like and it’s so ugly to me. i grew up in an abusive household and even i had hopes and dreams. in fact being hopeless and without motivation is a symptom of mental illness. idk i feel like the trope doesn’t work here or at least it shouldn’t have used in sansa’s arc

blog.name: whilereadingandwalking
blog.title: While Reading and Walking
blog.description: Leah Rachel von Essen. (she/her/hers). Book blogger, reporter, novelist. I read wherever I go, but I read the most while walking. I don’t trip. Because of magic.

summary: I wrote about Arya and Sansa Stark for Book Riot, and how their sisterhood reminded me of my own sister; I wrote about love and...
caption:
I wrote about Arya and Sansa Stark for Book Riot, and how their sisterhood reminded me of my own sister; I wrote about love and how people leave and come back together. “They didn’t have to grow towards each other,” I wrote, “They grew upwards, “the sun and the moon,” as Ned called them, and rotated around the same earth. They never got closer by literally closing the distance. They never dug into the other’s psyche. What they did is learn to appreciate what the other had. They each grew into their own full self, and then they looked at each other in the present moment and decided to stand together.”

The way the sisters learned to truly appreciate one another without the need to dig deep into the other’s lives or fall back into the past, the way Arya and Sansa began to stand in solidarity and support, was something I truly treasured about the final two seasons of Game of Thrones, and that hit me on a very personal level. Please check out my full piece on the Stark sisters at Book Riot. This is a piece I’m really proud of.

The way the sisters learned to truly appreciate one another without the need to dig deep into the other’s lives or fall back into the past, the way Arya and Sansa began to stand in solidarity and support, was something I truly treasured about the final two seasons of Game of Thrones, and that hit me on a very personal level. summary: I’m still just honestly baffled that Sansa and Tyrion weren’t endgame, and this isn’t even coming from me as a shipper, but as a...
body:
I’m still just honestly baffled that Sansa and Tyrion weren’t endgame, and this isn’t even coming from me as a shipper, but as a genuine fan of the show (and the books, but primarily talking about the show here).

I think even non-shippers can agree that D&D spent a LOT of time on the Sansa/Tyrion dynamic this season, with romantically coded dialogue and gestures thrown in for good measure. If you look back at the season, Sansa and Tyrion mention each other favorably or share a conversation in every single episode.

So much time and development was wasted on these characters and their relationship for it to come to absolutely nothing in the end. We didn’t even get a farewell scene, which even Jon and Tyrion got, and Jon is much less of an important character to Tyrion than Sansa is.

As with almost everything else in this show, I just keep coming back to the same question: what was the point?

As with almost everything else in this show, I just keep coming back to the same question: what was the point?

tags: parental favoritism damages your children Ned and Cat
summary: Random ASOIAF thought: I think a lot, if not most, of how mean Sansa is to Arya (apart from Septa Mordane being the sort of...
body:
Random ASOIAF thought:

I think a lot, if not most, of how mean Sansa is to Arya (apart from Septa Mordane being the sort of asshole who clearly encourages corrective bullying) stems from bitterness that Ned so clearly favors and indulges Arya.

Here’s Sansa, a perfect little lady who should be the absolute apple of any father’s eye–and she’s not. No, it’s Arya–plain, rambunctious, tomboyish Arya, who their mother despairs of making a lady–who is Daddy’s favorite daughter. And it kills her.

That Sansa resents the everloving hell out of Ned and Arya’s relationship is most obvious when Arya strays from the Kingsroad to pick wildflowers. Sansa wants their father to scold Arya for this breach of decorum so badly she can taste it–and instead, he just thanks his precious baby girl for the flowers she brought him. Catelyn and Septa Mordane would never have let Sansa get away with that, but Arya… well, as far as their father is concerned (in Sansa’s mind), Arya can do whatever she wants. 

Sansa is required to behave; Arya isn’t. And because she is a child, Sansa directs her resentment at her sister instead of her parents.

summary: Possible thing: when Petyr wasn't around Sansa, like when he was in the Vale of Arryn, he was sometimes late for important...
body: Possible thing: when Petyr wasn’t around Sansa, like when he was in the Vale of Arryn, he was sometimes late for important meetings because he didn’t want to interrupt his dream, in which Sansa was so gorgeous that he was ready to look at her forever. And even in a dream, looking at her from afar, he thought only about how beautiful she is and how much he love her.

reblog.comment: Possible thing: when Petyr wasn’t around Sansa, like when he was in the Vale of Arryn, he was sometimes late for important meetings because he didn’t want to interrupt his dream, in which Sansa was so gorgeous that he was ready to look at her forever. summary: Does sansa still blame arya for lady's death? In ACOK she did. Thinking that her father killed her in account of arya. But I...
question: Does sansa still blame arya for lady's death? In ACOK she did. Thinking that her father killed her in account of arya. But I don't if she still blame her
answer:
“Joffrey is a monster. He lied about the butcher’s boy and made Father kill my wolf”

While Sansa is still very traumatized at the start of A Clash of Kings and not thinking back on the events of the Trident, by A Storm of Swords she remembers clearly.

blog.name: dalekofchaos
blog.title: Fa la la It's off to Hell we go Cross your heart and hope to die
blog.description:
My name is Dallas. 
I am 26, Leo Sun Sagittarius Rising and Cancer Moon, INFP. Chaotic Neutral. Ambivert. I am Aroace, Autistic and have Cerebral Palsy. Slytherin, Plague Rat, Inmate W25Z,  Swiftie. Gray Jedi. My blog is Multifandom, Social Justice, Doctor Who, Harry Potter, ASOIAF, Star Wars, Star Trek, Stranger Things, Life Is Strange, Orphan Black, Carmilla, WWE, Marvel, DC, LOTR, Buffy, Hannibal, Horror, Emilie Autumn, Taylor Swift, Halsey, Lorde, and other music and whatever I post!

summary: My Ideal ending for the ASOIAF Books.
title: My Ideal ending for the ASOIAF Books.
body:
After the real war against The Others and the battle against Euron and Young Griff. What I think will happen is this. 

Daenerys will rebuild Valyria and lives in peace with her children, Dany finally has a home.

The Seven Kingdoms will separate to create democracy. Sansa rules The North. Shireen rules the Stormlands. Edmund rules The Riverlands. Asha rules The Iron Islands. Arianne rules Dorne. Myrcella rules The Westerlands. Willas or Margaery will rule The Reach. And Bran will rule The Crownlands

reblog.comment:

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: "Sansa decided that she would light a candle to the Mother Above the next time she visited the sept, and ask her to protect...
body:
“Sansa decided that she would light a candle to the Mother Above the next time she visited the sept, and ask her to protect Margaery from Joffrey’s cruelty. And perhaps a candle to the Warrior as well, for Loras.”

–Sansa 2, A Storm of Swords, George RR Martin

reblog.comment:
“Sansa decided that she would light a candle to the Mother Above the next time she visited the sept, and ask her to protect Margaery from Joffrey’s cruelty. And perhaps a candle to the Warrior as well, for Loras.”

summary: "In Sansa's dreams, her children looked like the brothers she had lost.  Sometimes there was even a girl who looked like Arya."
